key_points: Ransomware hackers avoid targeting Russia and friendly states, as suggested by malware coding.
This practice aligns with the interests of the Kremlin, avoiding domestic issues while fostering cyber activities abroad.
U.S. accuses Russia of harboring cybercriminals targeting Western enterprises, expected to be a discussion point in the Biden-Putin summit.
Putin hints at a hands-off approach towards hackers not violating Russian law.
Cybersecurity experts suggest a tacit deal between the Kremlin and hackers, allowing operations against the West without fear of domestic repercussions.
The Kremlin dismisses U.S. complaints, with Putin making light of accusations related to cybercrimes.
The economic fallout of the Soviet Union's collapse and subsequent job scarcity attributed to a rise in skilled hackers in Russia.
DarkSide and REvil, ransomware-as-a-service groups, select their partners carefully, avoiding any infiltration by Western intelligence.
Evidence linking ransomware attacks to Russia is contested by Russian cybersecurity experts.
Evgeniy Bogachev, the most-wanted cybercriminal with over $100 million siphoned from American bank accounts, reportedly resides in Russia untouched, suggesting Kremlin protection.
spokespersons: Dmitry Smilyanets (Former Hacker, Intelligence Analyst at Recorded Future)
